</DIV>



<DIV align="left">
<DIV style="font-size: 3pt; margin-top: 16pt; width: 18%; border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(a)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Based on formulas set forth in the Credit Agreement and not necessarily indicative of fair market
value (which could be materially higher or lower); receivables, inventory, intercompany notes,
and property, plant and equipment reflect net book value at
December&nbsp;31, 2006; equity of Ford
Credit is based on its book value at December&nbsp;31, 2006, and equity in other subsidiaries is based
on a multiple of their two-year average EBITDA less current debt.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(b)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Value reflects independent third party valuation of trademarks only.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Based on the Borrowing Base value of $22.5&nbsp;billion and the total outstanding amount of
debt secured by collateral of $7.4&nbsp;billion, the resulting collateral coverage ratio is 3.03.
Assuming the $11.5&nbsp;billion revolving credit facility were fully drawn and the $1.5&nbsp;billion of
non-loan exposure permitted under the facility were fully utilized, the collateral coverage ratio
would have been 1.13.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Events of Default</I>. In addition to customary payment, representation, bankruptcy and judgment
defaults, the Credit Agreement contains cross payment and cross acceleration defaults with respect
to other debt for borrowed money and a change in control default.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Automotive Credit Facilities</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2006, we had $1.5&nbsp;billion of other Automotive credit facilities, of which $1.1
billion constituted global unsecured credit facilities that could be used by any of our direct or
indirect majority-owned subsidiaries on a guaranteed basis. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, $1.4&nbsp;billion of
these facilities were available for use. All of the global unsecured credit facilities are free of
material adverse change clauses, restrictive financial covenants (for example, debt-to-equity
limitations and minimum net worth requirements), and credit rating triggers that would limit our
ability to obtain funding.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 27<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 15. DEBT AND COMMITMENTS </B><B><I>(Continued)</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B><I>Financial Services Sector</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Credit Facilities. </I>At December&nbsp;31, 2006, Ford Credit and its majority-owned subsidiaries,
including FCE Bank, plc (&#147;FCE&#148;), had $3.8&nbsp;billion of contractually-committed credit facilities with
financial institutions, of which $2.6&nbsp;billion were available for use. Of the lines available for
use, 26% (or $700&nbsp;million) are committed through June&nbsp;30, 2010, and the remainder are committed for
a shorter period of time. Of the $3.8&nbsp;billion, $1.1&nbsp;billion constitute Ford Credit facilities
($700&nbsp;million global and about $400&nbsp;million non-global) and $2.7&nbsp;billion are FCE facilities ($2.6
billion global and about $100&nbsp;million non-global). The global credit facilities may be used, at
Ford Credit&#146;s or FCE&#146;s option, by any of its direct or indirect majority-owned subsidiaries. Ford
Credit or FCE, as the case may be, will guarantee any such borrowings. All of the global credit
facilities have substantially identical contract terms (other than commitment amounts) and are free
of material adverse change clauses, restrictive financial covenants (for example, debt-to-equity
limitations and minimum net worth requirements) and credit rating triggers that could limit our
ability to obtain funding.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally,
at December&nbsp;31, 2006, banks provided $18.9&nbsp;billion of contractually-committed
liquidity facilities exclusively to support Ford Credit&#146;s two on-balance sheet, asset-backed
commercial paper programs; $18.6&nbsp;billion supported Ford Credit&#146;s retail securitization program
(&#147;FCAR&#148;) and $300&nbsp;million supported Ford Credit&#146;s Motown Notes<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: text-top">SM</SUP> wholesale
securitization program (&#147;Motown Notes&#148;). Of the contractually-committed liquidity facilities, 45%
(or $8.6&nbsp;billion) are committed through June&nbsp;30, 2011. The FCAR and Motown Notes programs must be
supported by liquidity facilities equal to at least 100% and 5%, respectively, of their outstanding
balance. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, $18.1&nbsp;billion of FCAR&#146;s bank liquidity facilities were available to
support FCAR&#146;s asset-backed commercial paper or subordinated debt. The remaining $500&nbsp;million of
available credit lines could be accessed for additional funding if FCAR issued additional
subordinated debt. Utilization of these facilities is subject to conditions specific to each
program and to Ford Credit having a sufficient amount of securitizable assets. At December&nbsp;31,
2006, the outstanding balances were $13.6&nbsp;billion for the FCAR program and $3&nbsp;billion for the
Motown Notes program.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Committed Liquidity Programs. </I>Ford Credit has entered into agreements with a number of
bank-sponsored asset-backed commercial paper conduits (&#147;conduits&#148;) and other financial institutions
pursuant to which such parties are contractually committed, at Ford Credit&#146;s option, to purchase
from Ford Credit&#146;s eligible retail or wholesale assets or to make advances under asset-backed
securities backed by wholesale assets for proceeds up to $29.1&nbsp;billion ($16.9&nbsp;billion retail and
$12.2&nbsp;billion wholesale). These committed liquidity programs have varying maturity dates, with
$20.8&nbsp;billion having an original term of 364&nbsp;days, and the balance having maturities between 2008
and 2011. Ford Credit&#146;s ability to obtain funding under these programs is subject to it having a
sufficient amount of assets eligible for these programs. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, $9.7&nbsp;billion of
these commitments were in use. These programs are free of material adverse change clauses,
restrictive financial covenants (for example, debt-to-equity limitations and minimum net worth
requirements) and credit rating triggers that could limit Ford Credit&#146;s ability to obtain funding.
However, the unused portion of these commitments may be terminated if the performance of the
underlying assets deteriorates beyond specified levels. Based on our experience and knowledge as
servicer of the related assets, we do not expect any of these programs to be terminated due to such
events.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, Ford Credit has a multi-year committed liquidity program for the purchase of up
to $6&nbsp;billion of unrated asset-backed securities that at its option can be supported with various
retail, wholesale, or lease assets. Ford Credit&#146;s ability to obtain funding under this program is
subject to it having a sufficient amount of assets available to issue the securities. This program
is also free of material adverse change clauses, restrictive financial covenants (for example,
debt-to-equity limitations or minimum net worth requirements), and credit rating triggers that
could limit Ford Credit&#146;s ability to obtain funding. Through December&nbsp;31, 2006, Ford Credit had
utilized $2.8&nbsp;billion. The programs was increased from $4&nbsp;billion to $6&nbsp;billion as of January&nbsp;1,
2007.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 28<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 16. SHARE-BASED COMPENSATION</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since January&nbsp;1, 2003, we have been expensing employee compensation pursuant to the provisions
of SFAS No.&nbsp;123, <I>Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation</I>. During the fourth quarter of 2005, we
adopted the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;123R, <I>Share-Based Payment</I>, under the modified prospective
method. We applied SFAS No.&nbsp;123R to new awards in 2006 and to any previous awards that were
modified, repurchased, or cancelled after the date of adoption of this standard.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2006, a variety of Ford stock-based compensation grants or awards were
outstanding for employees (including officers) and members of the Board of Directors. All
stock-based compensation plans are approved by the shareholders.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Description of Stock Option Plans</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We continue to measure the fair value of the majority of our stock-based compensation using
the Black-Scholes option-pricing model, using historical volatility and the simplified method of
calculating the expected term. Our expected term is calculated by averaging the vesting term (3
years) and the contractual term of the option (10&nbsp;years). Historical data is also used to estimate
option exercise behaviors and employee termination experience within the valuation model. Based on
our assessment of employee groupings and observable behaviors, we determined that a single grouping
is appropriate. Upon stock-settled compensation exercises and awards, shares were issued from
treasury stock. We do not expect to repurchase a significant number of shares for treasury stock
during 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have stock options outstanding under two Long-term Incentive Plans (&#147;LTIP&#148;), the 1990 LTIP
and the 1998 LTIP. No further grants may be made under the 1990 LTIP and all outstanding options
thereunder are exercisable. All outstanding options under the 1990 LTIP continue to be governed by
the terms and conditions of the existing option agreements for those grants. Grants may continue
to be made under the 1998 LTIP through April&nbsp;2008. Under the 1998 LTIP, 33% of the options are
generally exercisable after the first anniversary of the date of grant, 66% after the second
anniversary, and 100% after the third anniversary. Stock options expire ten years from the grant
date and are expensed using a three-year cliff vesting methodology.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We awarded performance-based stock options in 2006. The fair value of the performance-based
options was measured on the date of grant using the Monte Carlo simulation lattice model. This
model computes an expected term for the performance-based option grant and utilizes multiple input
variables that determine the probability of satisfying each market condition stipulated in the
award grant.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under the 1998 LTIP, 2% of our issued Common Stock as of December&nbsp;31 becomes available for
granting plan awards in the succeeding calendar year. Any unused portion is available for later
years. The limit may be increased up to 3% in any year, with a corresponding reduction in shares
available for grants in future years. At December&nbsp;31, 2006, the number of unused shares carried
forward was 95.9&nbsp;million shares.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock option activity was as follows:
</DIV>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">






<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 16. SHARE-BASED COMPENSATION </B><B><I>(Continued)</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The total fair value of options that vested during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005,
and 2004, was about $93&nbsp;million, $145&nbsp;million, and $184&nbsp;million, respectively. We have 203.2
million fully-vested stock options, with a weighted-average exercise price of $19.81 and remaining
term of 4.1&nbsp;years. We expect 51.4&nbsp;million stock options (after forfeitures), with a
weighted-average exercise price of $10.14 and remaining term of 8.6&nbsp;years to vest in the future.
The aggregate intrinsic value is <I>de minimis </I>for unvested and vested options at December&nbsp;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We received about $4&nbsp;million from the exercise of stock options in 2006. The tax benefit
realized was <I>de minimis</I>. An equivalent of about $4&nbsp;million in
treasury shares was used to settle
exercised options. For options exercised during the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004,
the difference between the fair value of the common shares issued and their respective exercise
price was about $1&nbsp;million, $9&nbsp;million, and $48&nbsp;million, respectively.
</DIV>

criterion. The key assumptions used for valuing the performance-based options during 2006 are as
follows:

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Share-Based Compensation</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pursuant to the 1998 LTIP we also grant other share-based awards to select executives and
other key employees, in addition to stock options. These awards include restricted stock,
restricted stock equivalents, performance stock rights, performance-based restricted stock
equivalents, and stock appreciation rights. These awards have various vesting criteria which may
include service requirements, individual performance targets, and company-wide performance targets.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 17. EMPLOYEE SEPARATION ACTIONS AND EXIT AND DISPOSAL ACTIVITIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Automotive Sector</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>General</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
have implemented a number of different employment separation actions
during 2006 and our
accounting for them is dependent on the individual benefit design. Jobs Bank Benefits (defined below) provided
to our hourly employees at facilities that will be idled by 2008 are expensed when it becomes
probable that the employees will be permanently idled. The cost of both hourly and salaried
voluntary employee separation actions are recorded at the time of the employee&#146;s acceptance, unless
the acceptance needs explicit approval by the Company. Conditional voluntary separations are
accrued for when all of the conditions are satisfied. Involuntary separation programs are accrued
for when management has approved the program and the affected employees are identified.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Jobs Bank Benefits Reserve</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2006, we announced a major business improvement plan for our North American Automotive
operations, which we refer to as the Way Forward plan. As part of this plan, we announced that the
following facilities would be idled through 2008: Atlanta Assembly Plant, Batavia Transmission
Plant, Essex Engine Plant in Canada, Maumee Stamping Plant, Norfolk Assembly Plant, St. Louis
Assembly Plant, Twin Cities Assembly Plant, Windsor Casting Plant in Canada and Wixom Assembly
Plant. We also announced a shift reduction in advance of idling the facilities at Norfolk and Twin
Cities and that production at our St. Thomas Assembly Plant in Canada would be reduced to one
shift. In addition, we announced that all Automotive Components Holdings, LLC (&#147;ACH&#148;) operations
would be sold or closed by the end of 2008.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Hourly employees working at the U.S. plants identified above are represented by the International
Union, United Automobile, Aerospace and Agricultural Implement Workers of America (&#147;UAW&#148;); hourly
employees working at the Canadian plants identified above are represented by the National
Automobile, Aerospace, Transportation and General Workers Union of Canada (&#147;CAW&#148;). Our collective
bargaining agreement with the UAW contains a guaranteed employment numbers provision, pursuant to
which we are required to pay idled employees who meet certain conditions substantially all of their
wages and benefits for the term of the current agreement; our collective bargaining agreement with
the CAW contains a provision pursuant to which we are required to pay idled employees a portion of
their wages and certain benefits for a specified period of time based on the number of credits an
employee has received. We refer to these benefits under the UAW and CAW agreements as &#147;Jobs Bank
Benefits.&#148;
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 31<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 17. EMPLOYEE SEPARATION ACTIONS AND EXIT AND DISPOSAL ACTIVITIES </B><B><I>(Continued)</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The plant idlings and shift reductions described above are expected to create a population of
covered hourly employees who will be permanently idled because we do not have the ability or intent
to redeploy or absorb them in our operations (the &#147;affected employees&#148;). The Jobs Bank Benefits
reserve (&#147;reserve&#148;) includes an amount for benefits expected to be provided in their present form
under the current UAW and CAW collective bargaining agreements, which are scheduled to expire in
September&nbsp;2007 and September&nbsp;2008, respectively, and an amount for similar benefits in an expected
modified form under new collective bargaining agreements after expiration of the current
agreements. During 2006, we recorded an expense of $2.6&nbsp;billion
for the Jobs Bank Benefits reserve.
The reserve balance is reduced for Jobs Bank Benefits payments made
to employees, and when
employees accept relocation packages. In addition, the reserve is adjusted for the estimated cost
of voluntary separation packages to be offered in lieu of Jobs Bank Benefits. As of December&nbsp;31,
2006, approximately 14,100 of the estimated 25,800 affected employees had accepted voluntary
separation packages (including those affected employees who accepted enterprise-wide buyout offers
described in the &#147;Other Actions&#148; section below). About 1,000 of the estimated 25,800 affected
employees had agreed to relocate to other facilities as of December&nbsp;31, 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Jobs Bank Benefits reserve balance at December&nbsp;31, 2006 was $1&nbsp;billion, and represents our
best estimate of the liability we will incur for the remaining 8,100 UAW-represented employees
(including ACH) and 2,600 CAW-represented employees at the facilities we plan to idle who have not
accepted a voluntary separation package. This amount takes into
account several factors: the demographics
of the population at each affected facility, redeployment alternatives, and recent experience
relative to voluntary redeployments. Due to the complexities inherent in estimating this reserve,
our actual costs could differ materially. We continue to expense costs associated with the small
number of employees who are temporarily idled on an as-incurred basis.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to the announced plant idlings and shift reductions discussed above, the Way
Forward plan includes additional plant idlings for which the specific facilities have not yet been
announced. We have not accrued any costs for benefits that may be provided to employees working at
these facilities. The execution of the plans for these facilities is dependent on the resolution
of many contingencies, including the negotiation of future labor agreements, the successful
implementation of our product cycle plan, the resolution of alternative capacity actions, and
changes in our market share between now and the planned idling of those facilities. Our current
estimate for the cost of benefits that we anticipate could be paid to employees at the remaining
facilities is about $700&nbsp;million (on a discounted basis). Although it is probable that we will
take the necessary actions to reduce our manufacturing employment, the amount of our estimated
benefit obligation is highly dependent on the resolution of the previously-mentioned contingencies.
No estimated value is more likely than another, and therefore, the benefit obligation is not
reasonably estimable.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Other Actions</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>UAW Voluntary Separations: </I>During 2006, we offered early retirement and voluntary separation
programs to all Ford and ACH hourly employees in the United States. These programs resulted in an
additional 22,300 voluntary separation acceptances, and we have recognized a pre-tax charge of $1.9
billion in 2006 related to these acceptances (separate from our Jobs Bank Benefits reserve
discussed above). Hourly employees in Ford North America who accepted
an early retirement or separation package are expected to leave the
Company by September 2007, though employees have an opportunity to
rescind acceptance until the time of separation. In 2005, approximately $88&nbsp;million of pre-tax charges were incurred for hourly
separations, of which approximately $62&nbsp;million was related to ACH.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 32<!-- /Folio -->
</div>
<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 17. EMPLOYEE SEPARATION ACTIONS AND EXIT AND DISPOSAL ACTIVITIES </B><B><I>(Continued)</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other Employee Separation Actions: </I>We announced in 2006 our plans to reduce North
American Automotive salaried-related costs through the elimination of the equivalent of about
14,000 positions (which included the equivalent of 4,000 positions already eliminated in the first
quarter of 2006). Through year-end 2006, about 850 additional
salaried employees had accepted separation packages, and we
recognized pre-tax charges of $25&nbsp;million for these acceptances in 2006. Most salaried reductions
are expected to be completed by the end of the first quarter of 2007 and will be achieved through
early retirements, voluntary separations, and if necessary, involuntary separations. In 2005, we
announced plans to reduce salaried positions in North America and incurred about $148&nbsp;million of
pre-tax charges related to these actions through December&nbsp;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2006 and 2005, Ford Europe initiated hourly and salaried employee separation actions
resulting in pre-tax charges of $109&nbsp;million and $297&nbsp;million for 2006 and 2005, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2006 and 2005, PAG initiated hourly and salaried employee restructuring actions
resulting in pre-tax charges of $160&nbsp;million and
$63&nbsp;million for 2006 and 2005, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2006 and 2005, our Ford Asia Pacific business unit initiated hourly and salaried
employee separation actions resulting in pre-tax charges of approximately $61&nbsp;million and $32&nbsp;million,
respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The above costs exclude costs for pension and other postretirement employee benefits (&#147;OPEB&#148;).
For further discussion, see Note 23 for employee separation costs related to pension,
postretirement health care and life insurance benefits.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financial Services Sector</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Business Restructuring</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2006, FCE announced a plan to restructure its business in Germany that supports the sales
activities of automotive financial services of Ford, Jaguar, Land Rover and Mazda vehicles. The
plan includes the consolidation of branches into district offices; these actions are expected to
reduce ongoing costs. We recognized pre-tax charges of $30&nbsp;million in 2006. The costs associated
with the business restructuring are primarily related to employee separations and were charged to
Financial Services <I>Operating and other expenses</I>. The restructuring will be completed in 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2004, we announced a plan to create an integrated sales platform in the United States and
Canada over the next two years that would support sales activities for Ford Credit and our other
business operating units. The plan included the consolidation of regional sales offices and an
integration of branch locations. We recognized pre-tax charges of $56&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31,
2006, including $4&nbsp;million in 2006 and $41&nbsp;million in 2005. The costs associated with the sales
branch integration are primarily related to employee separations and facility lease breakages and
were charged to<I> Operating and other expenses</I> as incurred. The integration was completed in 2006.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The table below summarizes the pre-tax charges incurred, the related liability at December&nbsp;31
and the estimated total costs related to these actions (in millions):
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">

    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="3"><B>December 31,</B></TD>

</TR>

    <TD nowrap align="left" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000"><B>Segment</B></TD>

<!-- End Table Head -->
<!-- Begin Table Body -->
<TR valign="bottom"  style="background: #cceeff">
    <TD><DIV style="margin-left:15px; text-indent:-15px">Ford Credit</DIV></TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">15</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">34</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD nowrap align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">(16</TD>
    <TD nowrap>)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">&#151;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">33</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="right">$</TD>
    <TD align="right">86</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2006, Ford Credit announced plans to consolidate and centralize most of its
originations and servicing operations in the United States to reduce costs and improve process
efficiencies. Most related salaried reductions are expected to be completed by the end of 2007 and
will be achieved through attrition, early retirements, voluntary separations, and if necessary,
involuntary separations. In 2006 and 2005, Ford Credit announced various separation programs for
North American and International salaried employees in connection with reorganization and
efficiency actions. Ford Credit recognized pre-tax charges of $9&nbsp;million and $36&nbsp;million in 2006
and 2005, respectively, as a result of these actions (excluding costs for retirement plan and
postretirement health care and life insurance benefits).
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 33<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 18. INCOME TAXES</B>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Annual tax provisions include amounts considered sufficient to pay probable assessments
for examination of prior-year tax returns by federal, foreign, state and local jurisdictions;
actual assessments may differ. We do not expect that such differences would have a material effect
on the future financial statements for a particular year, although such an outcome is possible. No
provision for deferred taxes has been made on $715&nbsp;million of unremitted earnings that are
considered to be indefinitely invested in non-U.S. subsidiaries. Deferred taxes for these
unremitted earnings are not practicable to estimate.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating loss carryforwards for tax purposes were $6.6&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2006. A
substantial portion of those losses have an indefinite carryforward period; the remaining losses
will begin to expire in 2007. Tax credits available to offset future tax liabilities are $2.6
billion. A substantial portion of these credits have a remaining carryforward period of 10&nbsp;years
or more; the remainder begins to expire in 2009. Tax benefits of operating loss and tax credit
carryforwards are evaluated on an ongoing basis, including a review of historical and projected
future operating results, the eligible carryforward period, and other circumstances. Effective
September&nbsp;30, 2006, the balance of deferred taxes primarily at our U.S., Jaguar, and Land Rover
entities has changed from a net deferred tax liability position to a net deferred tax asset
position. Due to the cumulative losses we have incurred at these operations and their near-term
financial outlook, we have established a valuation allowance of $7.2&nbsp;billion against the net
deferred tax asset.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2006, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) issued Interpretation No.&nbsp;48,
<I>Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes &#151; an interpretation of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;109 </I>(&#147;FIN
48&#148;). This interpretation prescribes a recognition threshold and a measurement attribute for the
financial statement reporting of tax positions taken in tax returns. The interpretation is
effective for fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2006. The Company will adopt the
interpretation as of January&nbsp;1, 2007 and management is expecting a $1&nbsp;billion to $1.5&nbsp;billion
increase to equity as a result of this adoption. The favorable impact to equity is the result of
recognizing refund claims and related interest for prior years that meet the &#147;more-likely-than-not&#148;
recognition threshold of FIN 48. These prior year refund claims and related interest were not
recognized as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 because they were considered gain contingencies under SFAS No.
5, <I>Accounting for Contingencies </I>and could not be recognized until the contingency lapsed.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective January&nbsp;1, 2006, we adopted the <I>Transition Election Related to Accounting for the
Tax Effects of Share-Based Payment Awards </I>under FASB Staff Position No.&nbsp;123(R)-3. The election
provides specific requirements for reporting the differences between the financial reporting of
share-based compensation and the related tax benefits.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 35<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 19. DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS, HELD-FOR-SALE OPERATIONS, OTHER DISPOSITIONS, AND ACQUISITIONS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Automotive Sector</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Discontinued Operations. </I>In 2004, the Automotive sector completed the disposition of several
of its non-core businesses initiated in 2002 and 2003, including our former automotive recycling
businesses in the United States and Canada, our electric vehicle business in Norway, and our
insurance-related products and services business in the United Kingdom. Associated with the
disposition of these entities, we recorded pre-tax charges of $9&nbsp;million in 2004, reflected in
<I>Income/(loss) from discontinued operations.</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2004, we sold our Formula One racing operations as these operations were not consistent
with our PAG Improvement Plan nor our goals to build on the basics and focus on our core business.
We recorded pre-tax charges of $204&nbsp;million for impairment of goodwill, $23&nbsp;million related to
write-down of inventory and $77&nbsp;million for loss on sale in 2004.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The results of all discontinued Automotive sector operations are as follows (in millions):

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, there were no significant assets or liabilities remaining
on our balance sheet related to discontinued operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Held-for-Sale Operations. </I>In 2005, we acquired the minority interest in the Beanstalk Group,
LLC, a majority-owned subsidiary that licensed trademarks, and subsequently sold our 100% interest.
Its operations were not consistent with our objective to focus on our core automotive business.
We recorded pre-tax charges of $53&nbsp;million for the impairment of intangible assets and goodwill in
<I>Automotive cost of sales </I>and $12&nbsp;million in <I>Automotive interest income and other non-operating
income/(expense), net </I>for the loss on sale in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2004, management committed to sell certain consolidated dealerships in the Ford Asia
Pacific and Africa/Mazda segment as the sale of the dealerships would allow us to concentrate on
the production and marketing of our products in the Asia Pacific region rather than the day-to-day
retailing operations. In 2004, we recorded pre-tax charges of $64&nbsp;million reflected in <I>Automotive
cost of sales </I>for the impairment of goodwill and $16&nbsp;million in <I>Automotive interest income and
other non-operating income/(expense), net </I>for the estimated loss on disposal. In 2005, we
completed the sale and recognized a pre-tax gain of $14&nbsp;million reflected in <I>Automotive interest
income and other non-operating income/(expense), net</I>.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, there were no assets or liabilities on our balance sheet
related to held-for-sale operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Other Dispositions. </I>In 2005, we completed the sale of our interests in Mahindra &#038; Mahindra
Ltd. (approximately 5% interest), Vastera, Inc. (approximately 19% interest), and Kwik-Fit Group
Limited (approximately 18% interest). As a result of the sales, we recognized pre-tax gains of
approximately $22&nbsp;million, $11&nbsp;million, and $152&nbsp;million, respectively in <I>Automotive interest
income and other non-operating income/(expense), net </I>in 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
also completed the exchange of 8.3&nbsp;million shares in Ballard
Power Systems Inc. (&#147;Ballard&#148;) for an
equity interest (50%) in NuCellSys, GmbH, a 50/50 joint venture with DaimlerChrysler Corporation.
As a result of the exchange and the retirement of certain restrictions, we recognized in <I>Automotive
cost of sales </I>a pre-tax charge of $61&nbsp;million in 2005. Our ownership interest in Ballard is 11.5%.
We continue to report this investment under the equity method.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 36<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 19. DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS, HELD-FOR-SALE OPERATIONS, OTHER DISPOSITIONS, AND ACQUISITIONS</B>
<B><I>(Continued)</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Acquisitions. </I>In December&nbsp;2006, we purchased Troller Veiculos Especiais LTDA (&#147;Troller&#148;), a
Brazilian manufacturer of vehicles in the light duty segment, for a present value cash amount of
$214&nbsp;million and liabilities amounting to $32&nbsp;million. We have agreed to pay $23&nbsp;million in 2007
and the remaining balance over the course of four years, which has been classified as debt. As part
of the transaction related to this acquisition, we have recorded an intangible asset of $246
million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2005, we finalized an agreement with Visteon Corporation (&#147;Visteon&#148;), our largest supplier,
in which we assumed control of 17 plants and 6 other facilities in the United States and
Mexico. These assets were transferred to ACH, a temporary business controlled and managed by
us, to protect the flow of critical parts and components in the near-term and, over time, to
improve our sourcing flexibility and cost competitiveness. We consolidated ACH on October&nbsp;1, 2005
as part of our Ford North America segment.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The total 2005 pre-tax loss from the transaction was $468&nbsp;million reflected in <I>Automotive cost
of sales</I>, summarized as follows (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As announced in the acceleration of our Way Forward plan on September&nbsp;15, 2006, all ACH
operations are to be sold or closed by the end of 2008. In support of the plan, ACH entered into
Memoranda of Understanding during December&nbsp;2006 for the sale of three ACH facilities; we expect to
formally complete the associated sale agreements with each of the buyers in the first half of 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2004, we acquired 100% ownership of ZF Batavia, LLC (renamed Batavia Transmissions, LLC)
from ZF Transmissions Technologies LLC. ZF Transmission Technologies LLC, is a company we jointly
own (49%) with ZF Friedrichshafen Germany (51%).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2000, we purchased the Land Rover sport utility vehicle business from the BMW Group.
As part of the acquisition, we agreed to pay two-thirds of the purchase price at closing with the
remainder being paid in 2005. During 2005, we made the final payment of approximately $1.3
billion.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financial Services Sector</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Discontinued Operations. </I>Consistent with our strategy to focus on our core business, we
completed the disposition of the operations discussed below.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2004, we committed to a plan to sell Triad Financial Corporation, our operation in the
United States that specialized in automobile retail installment sales contracts with borrowers who
generally would not be expected to qualify for traditional financing sources such as commercial
banks or automobile manufacturers&#146; affiliated finance companies. During 2005, we completed the
sale of this business and recognized a pre-tax loss of approximately $16&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 37<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2004, we completed the sale of AMI Leasing and Fleet Management Services, our operation in

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, there were no significant assets or liabilities remaining
on our balance sheet related to discontinued operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Held-for-Sale Operations. </I>In 2005, we sold our 100% ownership interest in Hertz as it is not
core to our Automotive business. As part of the transaction, we provided cash-collateralized
letters of credit in an aggregate amount of $200&nbsp;million to support the asset-backed portion of the
buyer&#146;s financing for the transaction. These letters of credit will expire no later than December
21, 2011. As a result of the sale, we recognized in <I>Gain on sale of Hertz, </I>a pre-tax gain of $1.1
billion, inclusive of $27&nbsp;million of charges to record the estimated fair value of the letters of
credit. For further discussion of these letters of credit, see Note 27.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, there were no assets or liabilities on our balance sheet
related to held-for-sale operations.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 20. CAPITAL STOCK AND AMOUNTS PER SHARE</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All general voting power is vested in the holders of Common Stock and Class&nbsp;B Stock. Holders
of Common Stock have 60% of the general voting power and holders of Class&nbsp;B Stock are entitled to
such number of votes per share as will give them the remaining 40%. Shares of Common Stock and
Class&nbsp;B Stock share equally in dividends, with stock dividends payable in shares of stock of the
class held. As discussed in Note 15, we are prohibited from paying dividends (other than dividends
payable in stock) under the terms of the Credit Agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If liquidated, each share of Common Stock will be entitled to the first $0.50 available for
distribution to holders of Common Stock and Class&nbsp;B Stock, each share of Class&nbsp;B Stock will be
entitled to the next $1.00 so available, each share of Common Stock will be entitled to the next
$0.50 so available and each share of Common and Class&nbsp;B Stock will be entitled to an equal amount
thereafter.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note 15, Convertible Notes with a principal amount of $4.95&nbsp;billion are
outstanding. At the option of the holder, each Convertible Note is convertible at any time on or
before December&nbsp;15, 2036, into shares of our Common Stock at a rate of 108.6957 shares per $1,000
principal amount of Convertible Notes (equivalent to a conversion price of $9.20 per share).
Conversion of all shares of such Convertible Notes would result in the issuance of 538&nbsp;million
shares of our Common Stock.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note 15, Trust II Preferred Securities with an aggregate liquidation
preference of $5&nbsp;billion are outstanding. At the option of the holder, each Preferred Security
is convertible, at any time on or before January&nbsp;15, 2032, into shares of our Common Stock at a
rate of 2.8249 shares for each Preferred Security (equivalent to a conversion price of $17.70 per
share). Conversion of all shares of such securities would result in the issuance of 282&nbsp;million
shares of our Common Stock.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 38<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Amounts Per Share of Common and Class&nbsp;B Stock</B>

account the effect of obligations, such as stock options and
convertible notes and securities, considered to
be potentially dilutive. Basic and diluted income/(loss) per share were calculated using the

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 22. DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS AND HEDGING ACTIVITIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operations are exposed to global market risks, including the effect of changes in foreign
currency exchange rates, certain commodity prices and interest rates. The objective of our risk
management program is to manage the financial and operational exposure arising from these risks by
offsetting gains and losses on the underlying exposures with gains and losses on derivatives used
to hedge them. We document our hedging objectives, practices, procedures, and accounting
treatment. In addition, we review our hedging program and our derivative positions, as well as our
strategy, on a regular basis.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our use of derivatives to manage market risk results in the risk of a counterparty defaulting
on a derivative contract. We establish exposure limits for each counterparty to minimize this risk
and provide counterparty diversification. We also enter into master netting agreements with
counterparties that usually allow for netting of certain exposures. Substantially all of our
counterparties have long-term debt ratings of single-A or better. The aggregate fair value of
derivative instruments in asset positions on December&nbsp;31, 2006, is $5.2&nbsp;billion, and represents the
maximum loss that would be recognized at the reporting date if all counterparties failed to perform
as contracted.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Hedge Accounting Designations</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have elected to apply hedge accounting to certain derivatives. Derivatives that receive
designated hedge accounting treatment are documented and evaluated for effectiveness in accordance
with our documentation. Some derivatives do not qualify for hedge accounting; for others, we elect
not to apply hedge accounting treatment. We have elected to apply the normal purchase and normal
sales classification to all physical supply contracts that are entered into for the purpose of
procuring commodities to be used in production within a reasonable time during the normal course of
our business.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Automotive Sector</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Cash Flow Hedges</I>. We use forward and option contracts to manage our exposure to foreign
currency exchange and commodity price risks. We apply the critical terms method of assessing
effectiveness for derivatives designated as hedging forecasted transactions. The effective portion
of changes in the fair value of cash flow hedges is deferred in <I>Accumulated other comprehensive
income/(loss) </I>(&#147;OCI&#148;) and is recognized in <I>Automotive cost of sales </I>when the hedged item affects
earnings. An amount is also reclassified from OCI and recognized in earnings if it becomes
probable that the original forecasted transaction will not occur. Our cash flow hedges mature
within three years or less. The exchange of cash associated with these derivative transactions is
reported as net cash flows from operating activities in our statements of cash flows.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Net Investment Hedges</I>. We use foreign currency forward exchange contracts to hedge the net
assets of certain foreign entities to offset the translation and economic exposures related to our
investment in these entities. We assess effectiveness based upon a comparison of the hedge with
the beginning balance of the net investment level hedged, with subsequent quarterly tests based
upon changes in spot rates to determine the effective portion of the hedge. Changes in
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 41<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 22. DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS AND HEDGING ACTIVITIES </B><B><I>(Continued)</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">the value of these derivative instruments, excluding the ineffective portion of the hedge, were
included in OCI as a foreign currency translation adjustment. The exchange of cash associated with
these derivative transactions is reported as net cash flows from operating activities in our
statements of cash flows.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Derivatives not designated as hedging instruments</I>. Some derivatives do not qualify for hedge
accounting treatment or we elect not to apply hedge accounting. We report changes in the fair
value of these derivatives through <I>Automotive cost of sales </I>or <I>Automotive interest income and other
non-operating income/(expense)</I>, <I>net </I>depending on the underlying exposure. The earnings impact
primarily relates to the revaluation of foreign currency derivatives and changes in fair value of
commodity derivatives and warrants. The exchange of cash associated with these derivative
transactions is recorded as net cash flows from investing activities in our statements of cash
flows.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Financial Services Sector</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ford Credit&#146;s overall risk management objective is to maximize economic value while limiting
the effect of changes in foreign currencies and interest rates. Ford Credit faces exposure to
currency exchange rates if a mismatch exists between the currency of its receivables and the
currency of the debt funding those receivables. Ford Credit executes cross-currency swaps and
foreign currency forwards to convert substantially all of the foreign currency debt obligations to
the local currency of the receivables. Interest rate swaps are used to manage exposure to
re-pricing risk, which arises when assets and the debt funding those assets have different
re-pricing periods that consequently respond differently to interest rate changes. Regardless of
hedge accounting treatment, derivative positions are used only to manage identified exposures.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Fair Value Hedges</I>. Ford Credit uses certain derivatives to reduce the risk of changes in the
fair value of liabilities. We designate receive-fixed, pay-float interest rate swaps as hedges of
existing fixed-rate debt. The risk being hedged is the risk of changes in the fair value of the
hedged item attributable to changes in the benchmark interest rate. For certain interest rate
swaps we use the dollar-offset method to assess hedge effectiveness. Hedge ineffectiveness is the
difference between the change in fair value of the entire derivative instrument and the change in
fair value of the hedged item. Ineffectiveness is recorded directly in earnings. The notional
balances for these highly effective interest rate swaps were $1.1&nbsp;billion, $1.8&nbsp;billion, and $13.1
billion at December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004, respectively. Other interest rate swaps meet the
specific criteria to assume no ineffectiveness in the hedge relationship. These interest rate
swaps had notional balances of $0, $3.8&nbsp;billion, and
$5.6&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005, and
2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Cash Flow Hedges</I>. Ford Credit has used certain derivatives to reduce the risk of the
variability of expected future cash flows. We designated receive-float, pay-fixed interest rate
swaps as hedges of existing floating rate debt. The risk being hedged was the risk of changes in
the cash flows of the hedged item attributable to changes in the benchmark interest rate. We used
the change in variable cash flows method to measure hedge ineffectiveness, which was the difference
between the change in the fair value of the float leg of the swap and the change in fair value of
the hedged item. Hedge ineffectiveness was recorded directly in earnings. Ford Credit had
notional balances of $0, $0, and $17.8&nbsp;billion in receive-float, pay-fixed interest rates swaps
classified as cash flow hedges at December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Net Investment Hedges</I>. Ford Credit has used foreign currency forward exchange contracts and
options to hedge the net assets of certain foreign entities to offset the translation and economic
exposures related to its investment in these entities. We assessed effectiveness based upon a
comparison of the hedge with the beginning balance of the net investment level hedged, with
subsequent quarterly tests based upon changes in spot rates to determine the effective portion of
the hedge. Ford Credit had notional balances of $0, $0, and $1.6&nbsp;billion in foreign currency
forwards and foreign currency options classified as net investment hedges at December&nbsp;31, 2006,
2005, and 2004, respectively. Changes in the value of these derivative instruments, excluding the
ineffective portion of the hedge, were included in OCI as a foreign currency translation
adjustment.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 42<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 22. DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS AND HEDGING ACTIVITIES </B><B><I>(Continued)</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<I>Derivatives not designated as hedging instruments</I>. We elect not to apply hedge accounting to
a majority of Ford Credit&#146;s derivatives. In addition, some of Ford Credit&#146;s derivatives would not
qualify for hedge accounting. We report changes in the fair value of these derivatives through
<I>Financial Services revenues</I>. The earnings impact primarily relates to interest rate swaps, which
are included in evaluating Ford Credit&#146;s overall risk management objective, and foreign currency
derivatives, which are offset by the revaluation of foreign denominated debt. The notional amount
of derivatives not designated for hedge accounting was
$158.7&nbsp;billion, $143.7&nbsp;billion, and $125.7
billion at December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We report the exchange of cash related to all of Ford Credit&#146;s derivative transactions,
regardless of designation, as net cash flows from investing activities in our statements of cash
flows.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Income Statement Effect of Derivative Instruments</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table summarizes the estimated pre-tax gains/(losses) for each type of hedge
designation described above for the Automotive and Financial Services sectors, for the years ended
December&nbsp;31 (in millions):
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<DIV style="font-size: 3pt; margin-top: 16pt; width: 18%; border-top: 1px solid #000000">&nbsp;</DIV>
</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR>

</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(a)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>These gains/(losses) related to foreign currency derivatives and were substantially offset by net revaluation impacts on foreign denominated debt, which
were recorded to the same income statement line item as the hedge gains/(losses).</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 3pt"><TD>&nbsp;</TD></TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap align="left">(b)</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Amount represents the portion of the derivative&#146;s fair value attributable to the change in foreign currency exchange rates.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 43<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Balance Sheet Effect of Derivative Instruments</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of derivatives reflects the price that a third party would be willing to pay or
receive in arm&#146;s length transactions and includes mark-to-market adjustments to reflect the effects
of changes in the related index. The following tables summarize the estimated fair value of our
derivative financial instruments at December&nbsp;31:

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We expect to reclassify for Automotive and Financial Services sectors existing net gains
of $188&nbsp;million from OCI to <I>Net income/(loss) </I>during the next twelve months as the underlying
exposures are realized.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 23. RETIREMENT BENEFITS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Employee Retirement and Savings Plans</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have two principal qualified defined benefit retirement plans in the United States. The
Ford-UAW Retirement Plan covers hourly employees represented by the UAW, and the General Retirement
Plan covers substantially all other Ford employees in the United States hired on or before December
31, 2003. The hourly plan provides noncontributory benefits related to employee service. The
salaried plan provides similar noncontributory benefits and contributory benefits related to pay
and service. Other U.S. and non-U.S. subsidiaries have separate plans that generally provide
similar types of benefits for their employees. We established, effective January&nbsp;1, 2004, a
defined contribution plan generally covering new salaried U.S. employees hired on or after that
date. Ford-UAW Retirement Plan expense accruals for UAW-represented Ford employees previously
assigned to Visteon (&#147;Visteon Hourly Employees&#148;) were charged to Visteon. Pursuant to definitive
agreements with Visteon signed on September&nbsp;12, 2005, these charges were discontinued effective
October&nbsp;1, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For our plans that provide benefits based on salary, we project employee future salary growth
for such salary-related benefits. Certain of our defined benefit pension plans provide benefits
that are not based on salary (e.g., U.S. Ford-UAW Retirement Plan, noncontributory portion of the
U.S. General Retirement Plan, and Canada Ford-UAW Retirement Plan). The salary growth assumption
is not applicable to these benefits.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 44<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 23. RETIREMENT BENEFITS </B><B><I>(Continued)</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Plan obligations and costs are based on existing retirement plan provisions. No assumption is
made regarding any potential future changes to benefit provisions beyond those to which we are
presently committed (e.g., in existing labor contracts).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In general, our plans are funded, with the main exceptions being certain plans in Germany and
U.S. defined benefit plans for senior management. In such cases, an unfunded liability is
recorded.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The expense for our worldwide defined contribution plans was $50&nbsp;million in 2006, $83&nbsp;million
in 2005 and $80&nbsp;million in 2004. This includes the expense for company matching contributions to
our primary employee savings plans (United States and Canada) of $0 in 2006, $44&nbsp;million in 2005
and $40&nbsp;million in 2004. Company matching contributions were suspended in July&nbsp;2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Postretirement Health Care and Life Insurance Benefits</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We, and certain of our subsidiaries, sponsor plans to provide selected health care and life
insurance benefits for retired employees. The Ford UAW
Hospital-Surgical-Medical-Drug-Dental-Vision Program (&#147;H-S-M-D-D-V Program&#148;) covers hourly
employees represented by the UAW, and the Ford Salary Health Care Plan covers substantially all
other Ford employees in the United States hired before June&nbsp;1,
2001. U.S. salaried employees hired
on or after June&nbsp;1, 2001 are covered by a separate plan that provides for annual company
allocations to employee-specific notional accounts to be used to fund postretirement health care
benefits. We also provide company-paid postretirement life insurance
benefits to U.S. salaried
employees hired before January&nbsp;1, 2004 and all U.S. hourly employees. Our employees generally may
become eligible for benefits when they retire; however, benefits and eligibility rules may be
modified from time to time.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective January&nbsp;1, 2007 for U.S. salaried employees hired before June&nbsp;1, 2001, we
established a company contribution limit set at 2006 levels for retiree health care benefits. U.S.
salaried employees hired on or after June&nbsp;1, 2001 participate in a defined contribution retiree
health care plan. In addition, for U.S. salaried employees hired before January&nbsp;1, 2004 who are
retirement eligible after June&nbsp;1, 2006, company-paid retiree life insurance benefits are limited to
$50,000 (employees hired on or after January&nbsp;1, 2004 do not receive company-paid life insurance
benefits). These benefit changes resulted in a reduction in 2006 and ongoing expense of about $400
million annually as well as a decrease in the year-end 2005 OPEB obligation of about $3&nbsp;billion.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective January&nbsp;1, 2008 for U.S. salaried employees hired before June&nbsp;1, 2001, we will
replace health care coverage (including prescription drugs and dental) for retirees and surviving
spouses who are age 65 and older or Medicare eligible with a new Health Reimbursement Arrangement
(&#147;HRA&#148;). Each such surviving spouse, retiree and his or her eligible spouse will be provided an
annual amount of up to $1,800 in an HRA account. The HRA may be used to help offset health care,
dental, vision and hearing costs. This benefit change resulted in a decrease in the year-end 2006
OPEB obligation of about $500&nbsp;million and a reduction in 2006 and ongoing expense of about $80
million annually.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As previously reported, we entered into an agreement with the UAW (&#147;Agreement&#148;) in December
2005 to increase retiree health care cost sharing as part of our overall cost reduction efforts.
On July&nbsp;13, 2006, we received the necessary court approval of a settlement of a lawsuit challenging
proposed modifications to the H-S-M-D-D-V Program and cost savings began to accrue as of that date.
The Agreement provides for increased cost sharing of health care expenses by retirees presently
covered under the H-S-M-D-D-V Program (&#147;Plan Amendment&#148;) and establishes an independent Defined
Contribution Retiree Health Benefit Trust (&#147;UAW Benefit Trust&#148;) which will serve as a non-Ford
sponsored Voluntary Employee Benefit Association. The UAW Benefit Trust will be used to mitigate
the reduction in health plan benefits for certain eligible present and future retirees, surviving
spouses and other dependents. This settlement agreement will remain in effect until September&nbsp;14,
2011, at which point either Ford or the UAW may provide notice of a desire to terminate the
Agreement.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 45<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTES TO THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>NOTE 23. RETIREMENT BENEFITS </B><B><I>(Continued)</I></B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Agreement provisions reduce significantly our share of health care costs. The Agreement
has been accounted for as a negative amendment to the H-S-M-D-D-V Program in the amount of $4
billion, net of $90&nbsp;million representing the present value of our commitment to fund the UAW
Benefit Trust (discussed below) discounted at 6.5%. We will amortize the negative plan amendment
on a straight-line basis over 12&nbsp;years (which represents the average remaining service period of
our active workforce). In addition we will accrete interest expense on the discounted value of the
funding commitment noted above. The interest expense recorded for 2006 was $2&nbsp;million. Our
year-end obligation was $62&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our commitment to fund the UAW Benefit Trust consists of three non-contingent cash payments
(&#147;buy-down&#148;) totaling $108&nbsp;million. We paid the first installment of $30&nbsp;million in cash to the
UAW Benefit Trust on August&nbsp;10, 2006. We are committed to make a second contribution of $35
million in 2009, and a third contribution of $43&nbsp;million in 2011.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The UAW Benefit Trust is controlled by the UAW Benefit Association Plan Committee
(&#147;Committee&#148;) which is appointed by the UAW. The Committee does not and will not include any
representatives of the Company. The Committee has the right to appoint an independent trustee
(&#147;Trustee&#148;) for purposes of managing the assets. The assets of the UAW Benefit Trust are the
responsibility of the Committee, which has full fiduciary responsibility for the investment
strategy, safeguarding of assets, and execution of the benefit plan as designed. Benefit payments
to eligible participants in the UAW Benefit Trust are limited in amount to the assets held by the
UAW Benefit Trust. Each year, the Committee will determine the level of benefits to be paid to
eligible participants. If the value of the assets in the UAW Benefit Trust is deemed insufficient
by the Trustee, the Trustee may accelerate our obligation for the second and third contribution to
the extent necessary to enable the UAW Benefit Trust to continue paying benefits.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As part of the Agreement, we also agreed to transfer to the UAW Benefit Trust the right to an
amount of cash determined by the appreciation of 8.75&nbsp;million shares of Ford Common Stock above
$8.145 per share. These stock appreciation rights are exercisable for three years from the
effective date of the Plan Amendment. One third of the 8.75&nbsp;million stock appreciation rights were
available on July&nbsp;13, 2006. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, these stock appreciation rights had not been
exercised. On the first anniversary of the effective date of the Agreement, another third of the
8.75&nbsp;million stock appreciation rights will become available and on the second anniversary, the
remaining stock appreciation rights will become available. We use a Black-Scholes model to measure
the fair value of the stock appreciation rights on a graded vesting schedule. We expensed $8
million related to the stock appreciation rights in 2006, recorded in <I>Automotive cost of sales</I>.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As part of the Agreement, UAW members also agreed to divert to the UAW Benefit Trust payments
of a previously-negotiated 2006 wage increase and a portion of negotiated cost-of-living increases
through 2011 as they are earned. In 2006, $44&nbsp;million of diverted wage increases were expensed.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The average annual cost savings to Ford from the Plan Amendment is projected to be $650
million, with projected average annual cash savings of $200&nbsp;million. The cost savings associated
with the amendment for 2006 is approximately $300&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio --> FS - 46<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2005, an agreement was reached with Visteon which included forgiving a receivable
related to Visteon&#146;s remaining UAW OPEB obligation and a portion of Visteon&#146;s salary obligation for
former Ford employees and retirees. The total receivable forgiven was about $800&nbsp;million, of which
$600&nbsp;million was recorded in 2004 as an allowance for doubtful receivables. At December&nbsp;31, 2006
and 2005, we had a long-term receivable of $127&nbsp;million and $140&nbsp;million, respectively,
representing Visteon&#146;s remaining responsibility for the benefits of the Visteon salaried employees.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Medicare Prescription Drug Improvement and Modernization Act of 2003 provides for a
federal subsidy to sponsors of retiree health care benefit plans that provide a benefit at least
actuarially equivalent to the benefit established by the law. We provide retiree drug benefits
that exceed the value of the benefits that will be provided by Medicare Part&nbsp;D, and our retirees&#146;
out-of-pocket costs are less than they would be under Medicare Part&nbsp;D. Therefore, we have
concluded that our plan is at least &#147;actuarially equivalent&#148; to the Medicare Part&nbsp;D plan and that
we will be eligible for the subsidy. We have reflected the impact of the subsidy by reducing our
2006, 2005, and 2004 expense by $270&nbsp;million, $290&nbsp;million, and $250&nbsp;million, respectively.
Beginning in 2008, the U.S. salary health care plan will no longer be eligible for the subsidy
receipt under Medicare Part&nbsp;D.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The measurement date for substantially all of our worldwide postretirement benefit plans is
December&nbsp;31. Our expense for defined benefit pension and OPEB benefits was as follows (in
millions):
</DIV>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 18pt"><B>FORD MOTOR COMPANY AND SUBSIDIARIES</B>

    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="15" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000"><B>Pension Benefits</B></TD>
